citation.article-title: Thiorhodococcus minus, gen. nov., sp. nov., A new purple sulfur bacterium isolated from coastal lagoon sediments.

p.s: Thiorhodococcus (Thi.o.rho.do.coâ€™ccus. Gr.n. thios sulfur; Gr.n. rhodos the rose; L.n.masc. coccus sphere; M.L.masc.n. Thiorhodococcus rose sphere with sulfur)
Mutiplication is by binary fission; motile.
Intracytoplasmic membrane system of vesicular type.
Photosynthetic pigments are bacteriochlorophyll a and carotenoids.
Phototrophic under anoxic conditions, facultatively chemotrophic under microoxic conditions.
Photoautotrophic growth with sulfide, sulfur, thiosulfate, and hydrogen as electron donors; during oxidation of reduced sulfur compounds, sulfur globules are transiently stored inside the cells.
In the presence of sulfide, organic compounds can be photoassimilated.
Belongs to the family Chromatiaceae, placed within the g-subgroup of Proteobacteria.
Habitat: surface layers of marine and brackish sediments containing hydrogen sulfide.
The mol% G+C of the DNA is 66.9 (HPLC).
Type species: Thiorhodococcus minus sp. nov.
